Class Invocation

java.lang.Object

org.postgresql.pljava.internal.DualState<String>
org.postgresql.pljava.internal.DualState.ListHead
org.postgresql.pljava.internal.LifespanImpl
org.postgresql.pljava.internal.Invocation
All Implemented Interfaces:
Lifespan
public class Invocation extends LifespanImpl
One invocation, from PostgreSQL, of functionality implemented using PL/Java.

This class is the Java counterpart of the struct Invocation_ in the C code, but while there is a new stack-allocated C structure on every entry from PG to PL/Java, no instance of this class is created unless requested (with current(); once requested, a reference to it is saved in the C struct for the duration of the invocation.

Author:
Thomas Hallgren

  • Field Details

    • s_unhandled

      static SQLException s_unhandled
      Recent exception representing a PostgreSQL ereport(ERROR that has been thrown in Java but not yet resolved (as by rollback of the transaction or subtransaction / savepoint).

      Mutation happens on "the PG thread".

      This field should be non-null when and only when errorOccurred is true in the C Invocation struct. Both are set when such an exception is thrown, and cleared by clearErrorCondition.

      One static field suffices, not one per invocation nesting level, because it will always be recognized and cleared on invocation exit (to any possible outer nest level), and errorOccurred is meant to prevent calling into any PostgreSQL functions that could reach an inner nest level. (On reflection, that reasoning ought to apply also to errorOccurred itself, but that has been the way it is for decades and this can be added without changing that.)

      On the first creation of a ServerException, that exception is stored here. If any later call into PostgreSQL is thwarted by finding errorOccurred true, the ServerException stored here will be replaced by an UnhandledPGException that has the original ServerException as its cause and the new exception will be thrown. Once this field holds an UnhandledPGException, it will be reused and rethrown unchanged if further attempts to call into PostgreSQL are made.

      At invocation exit, the C popInvocation code knows whether the exit is normal or exceptional. If the exit is normal but errorOccurred is true, that means the exiting Java function caught a ServerException but without rethrowing it (or some higher-level exception) and also without resolving it (as with a rollback). That is a bug in the Java function, and the exception stored here can have its stacktrace logged. If it is the original ServerException, the logging will be skipped at levels quieter than DEBUG1. If the exception here is already UnhandledPGException, then at least one attempted PostgreSQL operation is known to have been thwarted because of it, and a stacktrace will be generated at WARNING level.

      If the invocation is being popped exceptionally, the exception probably is this one, or has this one in its cause chain, and longstanding code in JNICalls.c::endCall will have generated that stack trace at level DEBUG1. Should that not be the case, then a stacktrace of this exception can be obtained from popInvocation by bumping the level to DEBUG2.

      Package access so factory methods of ServerException and UnhandledPGException can access it.
